newsitem.title: GERMANY: KAL adds 0.15 marks/kg cargo surcharge.
newsitem.headline: KAL adds 0.15 marks/kg cargo surcharge.

text.p: Korean Air Lines said it will apply an ex-Germany air cargo fuel surcharge of 0.15 German marks per kilogramme from November 1.
KAL Germany cargo sales manager Robert Instinsky said the airline would follow exactly the terms of the Lufthansa Cargo rise announced last Friday.
Industry sources said the Korean surcharge will also apply to other continental European airports but no decision has yet been taken for the U.K..
Lufthansa said it would levy per kg a surcharge of 10 U.S. cents or the equivalent in the local currency from November 1 but would drop it once jet fuel prices returned to July 1996 levels.
Instinsky told Reuters: "I expect there will be no difficulties among the forwarders for this rise since these are operational costs."
Instinsky noted that fuel costs had risen dramatically for Korean Air Lines since the summer.
Other Asian airlines were considering similar ex-Germany surcharges, he added.

European airlines which have already announced fuel surcharges include Air France, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Swissair and Cargolux whilst Brazil's Varig has also announced an ex-Germany surcharge of 0.15 marks per kg.
